A variable is a place holder for data which we can use in our programs. We have four basic data types at our disposal in Python, integer, float, string, float. You can declare a new variable by using any of the given sequences of characters and more: x = 0, “hello world”, y = 2.5, z = True. Once the variable has been declared in the interpreter you can now call a function on it to see the literal value of the data.
You can declare a variable with this sequence of characters: x = 0

To display the data on the screen we will call the print function as such: print(). Here we are passing data to the print function: print(“Hello everybody I\’m a string”). In turn the interpreter will then display a string on the screen.
You can display data on the screen with the print() function.

To check if one value is exactly equal to the other we can use the “exactly equal” operator ==. For instance we could have two variables in our code; f = 960 and I = 349. We can use the print function to get the answer with sequence: print(f==I). This will display False, another type of data called a boolean value.
To check if I is equal to f we can use the command type(f+I).
